dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Misty night. The moon is reflected in the canal. A gondol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO ROBED MEN (SENATORS) walk briskly towards the Doge's TWO CAPTAINS approach from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP: 16th century map of the Mediterranean by the fli We pull back to see that the map is spread across a large SEVERAL ELDERLY SENATORS, lavishly dressed and dripping j The DOGE (DUKE) OF VENICE sits by the fireside playing ch

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
dialogues.text: There is no composition in these news  That gives them credit.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND SENATOR
dialogues.text: Indeed they are disproportioned My letters say a hundred and seven galleys.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
dialogues.text: And mine a hundred and forty. A TURKISH EMISSARY arrives with a scroll. A SOLDIER deliv Sultan of the Turks to the Signory of Venice:  'We demand of you Cyprus, which you shall give  willingly or perforce. Beware, therefore,  lest you arouse our wrath for we shall wage  most cruel war against you everywhere.'  (1570)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes the scroll to his Senators. There is a flurry o

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Tis certain then, for Cyprus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The veiled figure rounds a corner into a seedy back stree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three men stand silently, tensely: A PRIEST, a handsome S The door bursts open. The men rise. The veiled figure sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello and Desdemona stand before the Priest. Othello fu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A richly DRESSED GENTLEMAN (RODERIGO) and a SOLDIER (IAGO

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I take it much unkindly that thou, Iago, Shouldst know of this. Othello brings out a sash and places it across Cassio's s

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: By the faith of man, 1 know my price, I am worth no worse a place;  But he, that never set a squadron in the field, Nor the division of a battle knows, More than a spinster, must his Lieutenant be,  And I, of whom his eyes had seen the proof - God bless the mark - his moorship's Ancient. Cassio cannot contain his smile. They clasp hands. Othell Othello and Desdemona are now alone. They move towards ea Roderigo turns away in disgust. He pulls Iago beneath the

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: By heaven, I rather would have been his hangman.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why, there's no remedy. 'Tis the curse of service:

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I would not follow him then.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O, Sir, content you: I follow him to serve my turn upon him. We cannot all be masters, nor all masters Cannot be truly followed. You shall mark Heaven is my judge, not I for love and duty, But seeming so for my peculiar end: I am not what I am.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: What a full fortune does the thick lips owe If he can carry't thust.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Call up her father. Roderigo considers, then sets off. Iago turns and looks d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassio lots himself quietly into the chamber. The Senators pore over the map.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: But who should lead our business against the Turkish flee They exchange thoughtful glances.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Othello?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND SENATOR
dialogues.text: Marcos Luccicos, is not he in town?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
dialogues.text: He's now in Florence. Othello?  The other Senators look disapprovingly at the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
dialogues.text: Another of his fathom we have none.  The Duke turns to Lodovico.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: The fortitude of the place is best known to him.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Fetch Othello hither.  Cassio leaves the room, followed by two attendants

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago and Roderigo approach BRABANTIO'S HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD MAN (BRABANTIO) lies asleep in his bed. He mumbles

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: What, ho, Brabantio! Signor Brabantio, ho!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Awake! What, ho, Brabantio! Thieves, thieves! Look to your house, your daughter!  Brabantio sits bolt upright, as if waking from a nightmar

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: ... and your bags! Thieves, thieves!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roderigo and Iago shouting "Awake", "Brabantio", "Magnifi

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: (peering into the darkness) What is the reason of this terrible summons? What is the Iago urges Roderigo to speak.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (nervously) Signor, is all your family within?

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: I know thee, Roderigo, And have charged thee not to haunt about my doors; In honest plainness thou hast heard me say My daughter is not for thee.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Are your doors locked?

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Why, wherefore ask you this?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Zounds, sir, you're robbed; for shame, put on your gown; Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soul.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: What, have you lost your wits?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Even now, now, very now, an old black ram Is tupping your white ewe. Arise I say!

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: What profane wretch art thou?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I am one, sire that comes to tell you, your daughter and

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Thou art a villain.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You are a senator.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: This thou shalt answer, Roderigo...

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Sir, I will answer anything; but I beseech you,  Straight satisfy yourself; If she be in your chamber or your house,  Let loose on me the justice of the state For thus deluding you.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Strike on the tinder, ho! Give me a taper; call up all my people!  Brabantio mutters to himself, struggling for breath:

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: This accident is not unlike my dream: Belief of it oppresses me already. (yelling) Light, I say, light!  Brabantio goes back into his room. Sounds of commotion. Iago congratulates Roderigo with a firm shake of the hand Roderigo gives him a purse.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Farewell, for I must leave you.  Roderigo tries to grab him, but Iago eludes him and goes. Brabantio comes out of his front door into the street. A BAND OF MEN carrying torches gather at his side.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: It is too true an evil. Gone she is. Do you know where we may Apprehend her and the Moor?

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I think I can discover him.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: O, that you had had her. (shouting to his Servants) Get weapons, Ho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassio, his two Attendants and Iago stand motionless in t Othello steps out of the chapel to join them. He scoops u

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I pray you, sir, are you fast married?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Sir, you have been hotly called for.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Have with you.  They march off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello and his Men appear from one side. Brabantio's fro Brabantio draws his sword. The sound of swords whipped fr Roderigo is terrified to find himself in the middle of th

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You, Roderigo? Come, air, I am for you. He draws the confused Roderigo to one side.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Hold your hands, Both you of my inclining and the rest, Were it my cue to fight, I should have known it  Without a prompter.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: O thou foul thief Where hast thou stowed my daughter? Damned as thou art, thou hast enchanted her, T'run from her guardage to the sooty bosom Of such a thing as thou? Lay hold upon him.  Brabantio's Men make for Othello. Othello's Men prepare t

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Keep up your bright swords for the dew will rust'em Good Signor, where will you that I go to answer this your

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: To Prison, til fit time Of law and course of direct session call thee to answer.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What if I do obey? How many the Duke be therewith satisfied, Whose messengers are here about my side, To bring me to him?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: 'Tis true, most worthy Signor: The Duke's in council, and your noble self I am sure is sent for.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: How? The Duke in council? In this time of night? Bring hi Brabantio sets off. Othello rebuffs the arms that try to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Othello enters, Brabantio, Iago, Roder

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Valiant Othello, we must straight employ you Against the general Turkish foe. Brabantio pushes his way forward.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: I did not see you: Welcome, gentle Signor; We lacked your counsel and your help tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: So did I yours. Good your grace, pardon me: Neither my place, nor aught I heard of business, Hath raised me from my bed...

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Why? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: My daughter! O, my daughter!

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Dead?

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Ay, to me. She is abused, stolen from me, and corrupted. For nature so preposterously to err, Sans witchcraft could not.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Whoe'er he be that in this foul proceeding Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself And you of her, the bloody book of law You shall yourself read in the bitter letter After your own sense, yea, though our proper son Stood in your action.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Humbly I thank your grace. Here is the man. He indicates Othello. An embarrassed silence.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
dialogues.text: We are very sorry for't.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: (to Othello) What in your own part can you say to this?

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Nothing but this is so.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Most potent grave and reverend signors, My very noble and approved good masters, That I have ta'en away this old man's daughter, It is most true; Gasps of shock and outrage, setting off a series of whisp

dialogues.speaker: OTHELL
dialogues.text: O true I have married her; The whispering grows louder.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: The very head and front of my offending Hath this extent, no more. Roderigo gasps indignantly. The Duke silences the noise.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Rude am I in my speech And little blessed with the soft phrase of peace Since these arms of mine had seven years' pith  Till now some nine moons wasted, they have used  Their dearest action in the tented field And little of this great world can I speak More than pertains to feats of broil and battle; And therefore little shall I grace my cause In speaking of myself. Yet, by your gracious patience, I will round unvarnished tale deliver Of my whole course of love: what drugs, what charms,  What conjuration and what mighty magic - For such proceedings am I charged withal - I won his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: A maiden never bold;  of spirit so still and quiet that her motion  Blushed at herself - and she in spite of nature  To fall in love with what she feared to look on!

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I do beseech you, send for the lady And let her speak of me before her father. If you do find me foul in her report, The trust, the office I do hold of you Not only take away, but let your sentence Even fall upon my life. All eyes turn to the Duke. The Duke turns to Brabantio, w

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Fetch Desdemona hither. Othello gestures to Iago who leaves with two Attendants.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Speak, Othello.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Her father loved me, oft invited me, Still questioned me the story of my life From year to year - the battles, sieges, fortunes, That I have passed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brabantio and Othello walk together in a bright, sunlit g Brabantio listens intently as Othello tells his story.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Wherein I spoke of most disastrous chances,  Of moving accidents and hair-breadth scapes,  Of being taken by the insolent foe, And sold to slavery. Desdemona sits behind them. Her hair spread out for blond IN CLOSEUP we see she is peeking through her hair. She av

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And of the Cannibals that each other eat, The Anthropophagi, and men whose heads Do grow beneath their shoulders. This to hear Would Desdemona seriously incline... And with a greedy ear Devour up my discourse; which I observing...

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DAY
dialogues.text: Twilight in the garden. We find Othello and Desdemona in

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Took once a pliant hour, and found good means  To draw from her a prayer of earnest heart  That I would all my pilgrimage dilate.  I did consent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brabantio, seething with anger, turns to the Duke. The Du

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... and ran it through even from my boyish days To the very moment that he bade me tell it. CLOSEUP on Desdemona's face, on which the following monta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flames. A white arm drops a flaming torch... Frantic figu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY OTHELLO runs fast and scared across a ravine. The

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy Othello... strikes, with a staff at his Father wh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Othello... strikes again, with a sword, at TWO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Othello - Shackled to other prisoners of war is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello, bare-chested, catches a gun that's thrown at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello in MILITARY UNIFORM, fighting side by side with I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The images fade from Desdemona's face to reveal tears on

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My story being done, She gave me for my pains a world of sighs: She swore, in faith: t'was strange, t'was passing strange 'Twas pitiful, t'was wondrous pitiful; She wish'd she had not heard it, yet she wished That heaven had made her such a man. Othello puts on his coat and prepares to leave. He gives her the handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She thanked me,  And bade me: if I had a friend that loved her,  I should but teach him how to tell my story,  And that would woo her. They look into each other's eyes. She puts her hand slowl

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She loved me for the dangers I had passed, And I loved her that she did pity them.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: This only is the witchcraft I have used. All eyes turn to the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona stops outside the door. Iago stands behind her. Iago steps in and assists. He smiles calmly at her. She s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens onto Desdemona. All eyes turn to her.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Come hither, gentle mistress; Do you perceive in all this company Where most you owe obedience?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: My noble father,  To you I am bound for life and education;  My life and education both do learn me How to respect you. You are lord of all my duty, I am hitherto your daughter. But here's my husband; And so much duty as my mother showed To you, preferring you before her father, So much I challenge, that I may profess Due to the Moor, my lord. Brabantio's face creases in pain. Roderigo, likewise.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: God bu'y! I have done.  I had rather to adopt a child than get it.  Come hither, Moor: I here do give thee that with all my heart  Which, but thou hast already, with all my heart  I would keep from thee. Brabantio takes his daughter's hand and places it in Othe As Brabantio turns away, his face contorts again and he c

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: I humbly beseech you proceed to th'affairs of state. The Duke waits until Brabantio is safely seated.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for Cyprus.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: With all my heart. Most humbly therefore bending to your state, I crave fit disposition for my wife, Due reference of place and exhibition, With such accommodation and resort As levels with her breeding. There is a murmur of disapproval amongst the Senators.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Why if you please, Be't at her father's.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: I'll not have it so.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Nor I.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Nor I: I would not there reside To put my father in impatient thoughts By being in his eye. Most gracious Duke

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: What would you, Desdemona?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: That I did love the Moor to live with him My downright violence and scorn of fortunes May trumpet to the world: My heart's subdued Even to the utmost pleasure of my lord; I saw Othello's visage in his mind, And to his honours, and his valiant parts Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate: So that, dear lords, if I be left behind, A moth of peace, and he go to the war, The rites for which I love him are bereft me, And I a heavy interim shall support, By his dear absence.-lot me go with him.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Let her have your voice. And heaven defend your good souls that you think I will your serious and great business scant For she is with me. The Duke glances at the ailing Brabantio.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: Be it as you shall privately determine, Either for her stay, or going. At nine i'th'morning, here we'll meet again Good night to everyone. And, noble Signor, He beckons Brabantio and draws him to one side.

dialogues.speaker: DUKE
dialogues.text: If virtue no delighted beauty lack, Your son-in-law is far more fair than black. Desdemona sees that Othello has overheard this and is not The Duke leaves.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
dialogues.text: Adieu, brave Moor. (he leaves)

dialogues.speaker: SECOND SENATOR
dialogues.text: Use Desdemona well. Othello is immediately riled, but Desdemona calms him.

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Look to her, Moor, if thou hast eyes to see. She has deceived her father and may thee.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: My life upon her faith! Brabantio leaves.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Honest Iago, My Desdemona must I leave to thee. I prithee let thy wife attend on her, And bring them after in the best advantage. Come Desdemona, we must obey the time. Othello and Desdemona leave and Iago is about to follow.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Iago. Iago turns back to the apparently empty room. Roderigo st

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What say'st thou, noble heart?

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: What will I do, think'st thou?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why, go to bed and sleep.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I will incontinently drawn myself. O, Desdemona.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: If thou dost I shall never love thee after. Why thou silly gentleman!

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: It is silliness to live when to live is a torment.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O villainous! Iago sits in the Duke's chair and pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I have looked upon the world. For four times seven years,

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: What should I do? I confess it is my shame to be so fond,

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Virtue? A fig! 'Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: It cannot be.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of the He gets a smile out of Roderigo.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I have professed me thy friend and I confess me knit to t Roderigo looks skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I say, put money in thy purse. It cannot be that Desdemon He encourages Roderigo to join in...

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: ... money in thy purse. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: A pox on drowning, tis clean out of the way. Seek thou ra

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Wilt thou be fast to my hopes? Roderigo dangles a purse. Iago pushes it away.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Thou art sure of me. There are many events in the womb of Roderigo sets off contentedly. A thought occurs and he re

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Where shall we meet i'th' morning?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: At my lodging.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (contented again) I'll be with thee betimes.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Go to; farewell. (calling him back) Do you hear, Roderigo?

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (returning again) What say thou?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: No more of drowning, do you hear?

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (laughing) I am changed. Iago flashes his palm. Roderigo automatically drops his p

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Go to: Farewell.  (calling out again) Put money enough in your purse.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (returning again) I'll sell all my land. They both laugh as Roderigo leaves. Iago turns to address

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Thus do I ever make my fool my purse: For I mine own gain He studies the Duke's chessboard.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Cassio's a proper man: Let me see now; To got his place and to plume up my will In double knavery. How? He looks into the Camera as if it had made a suggestion:

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: How? He turns back to the chessboard.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Let's see. Iago's face is impassive, though his features seem to dan

dialogues.text: Brabantio lies in bed, his face contorted in pain. HIS BR Brabantio turns his stare on her and tries to speak. She

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: O, treason of the blood. Tearful and angry, Desdemona unhooks his fingers from her

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: O who would be a father. His features relax. He is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP on empty chessboard. Iago's hand puts the black k

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I have't. It is engendered. His stares into the fire. The fire is reflected in his ey

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Hell and night. Must bring this monstrous birth to th' wo He pockets the three pieces. He toasts the Camera, emptie He picks up one end of the map and , with a flick of the

dialogues.text: A robe flows back and forth with the tide. We see a dead

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (shouts) A sail, a sail, a sail!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soldiers fire the cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance we see the ships out at sea. In the foreground, a rowing boat is pulled to shore. Cass

dialogues.speaker: MONTANO
dialogues.text: Cassio Thanks you the valiant of this worthy isle That so approve the Moor, and let the heavens, Give him defense against their elements, For I have lost him on a dangerous sea. They see another boat arriving further down the shore - i

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: O behold, the riches of the ship Is come ashore. They set off towards the boat. Cassio strides into the wa

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Hail to thee lady! And the grace of heaven, Before, behind thee, and on every hand, Enwheel thee round. He kisses her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I thank you valiant Cassio. What tidings can you tell me of my lord?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: He is not yet arrived; nor know I aught But that he's well, and will be shortly here.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: O, but I fear! She looks out across the sea. Cassio leads her inland.  In the background Iago and Roderigo (now disguised in a b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new arrivals are travelling. A horse-drawn litter car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party climb the hill to the castle. Cassio leans acro

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) He takes her by the palm; Ay, smile upon her do.  The castle appears ahead of them. SOLDIERS peer down from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona steps out of the litter:

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: You men of Cyprus let her have your knees.  OFFICERS and SOLDIERS bow. Iago arrives followed by Emili

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: (to Iago) Good Ancient, you are welcome.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: (to Emilia) Welcome, mistress. Let it not gall your patience, good Iago, That I extend my manners. 'Tis my breeding That gives me this bold show of courtesy.  Cassio kisses Emilia.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Sir, would she give you so much of her lips As of her tongue she oft bestows on me, You'd have enough.  He gets a laugh from the assembled Soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Alas, she has no speech.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: In faith, too much. I find it still when I have list to sleep.  More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: You shall not write my praise.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: No, let me not.  Desdemona looks troubled. Cassio comforts her.  Iago takes out a knife and cuts a piece of fruit. He glim

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Very good. Ay, well said, whisper. With as little a web a Roderigo taps him on the shoulder and is about to speak -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello rides into the courtyard. Desdemona steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: O, my fair warrior!

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear Othello.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: It gives me wonder great as my content To see you here before me. O my soul's joy! I cannot speak enough of this content; It stops me here; it is too much of joy. They kiss repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: And this, and this the greatest discords be That e'er our hearts shall make.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O, you are well tuned now! But I'll set down the pegs that make this music, As honest as I am.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: News, friends; our wars are done; the Turks are drowned. This desperate storm Hath seen a grievous wrack and sufferance On most part of their fleet.  Cheers of jubilation. Othello spots Montano and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: How does my old acquaintance of this Isle? Honey, you shall be well desired in Cyprus: I have found great love amongst them. O my sweet, I prattle out of fashion and I dote In mine own comforts.  She laughs and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: And besides the mere perdition of the Turkish fleet It is the celebration of our general's nuptial.  The lovers embrace again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOLDIER lights a candle.

dialogues.speaker: CASTLE
dialogues.text: Lit up with candles.

dialogues.speaker: -THE CASTLE
dialogues.text: The castle is being prepared for the celebrations: Banners are unfurled. Statuary being polished etc. Women applying make-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO MAIDS adorn the bed with rose petals, oranges and app

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dining table is being prepared. A SERVANT knocks a monkey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilia arranges pearls in Desdemona's hair -

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Rubbing gum resin into black breeches.  Gold dust sprinkled over Desdemona's hair  Gold dust sprinkled over Othello'S breeches  Cassio arrives and extends an arm towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello and guests sit in silence. They include Iago, Emi Desdemona appears, escorted by Cassio. A musical sextet p Othello leaps onto the table and performs a Moorish dance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roderigo, dejected, sits on the grass, drinking from a bo SOLDIERS and CYPRIOT CIVILIANS sit by bonfires, eating, d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dancing continues. Othello beckons Cassio to dance wi

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Heaven bless the isle of Cyprus.

dialogues.speaker: MONTANO
dialogues.text: And our worthy general, Othello.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: He hath achieved a maid, That paragons descriptions and wild fame, One that excels the quirks of blazoning pens, And in the essential vesture of creation Does bear all excellency.  DOVES dyed in many colours are released into the room.  The other men join in the dance around Desdemona. Othello Cassio pulls Iago aside and whispers in his ear. Othello

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DRUNKEN SOLDIER pulls a striking WOMAN (BIANCA) out of The Cypriot pushes him down. A number of SOLDIERS leap to Iago, now in military uniform, steps in with bottles of w

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Heaven bless this isle and the  perdition of the Turkish fleet.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Heaven bless this isle. Iago kisses Bianca himself and gets an appreciative laugh Bianca looks up and sees Cassio at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassio smiles nervously at Bianca and backs away from the

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Good Michael, look you to the guard tonight. Let's teach ourselves that honourable stop, Not to outsport discretion.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Iago hath direction what to do;  But notwithstanding with my personal eye  Will I look to't.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Iago is most honest. Michael, good night.  They salute one another and Cassio reaches for Desdemona'

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Come my dear love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roderigo is wedged against the wheel of a cart. A pair of Roderigo crawls drunkenly under the cart to join him.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: If thou be'st valiant - as they say base men being in lov Roderigo senses this may be an insult, but is too inebria

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: - list me. The Lieutenant tonight watches on the court of

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: With Cassio? Why, 'tis not possible. Forgetting his location, Roderigo leaps up and bangs his

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Lay thy finger thus and let thy soul be instructed. Mark

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (nursing his head) I cannot believe that in her: she's full of most blessed

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Blessed fig's end! The wine she drinks is made of grapes.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Yes, that I did: But that was but courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Lechery, by this hand:  Much to Roderigo's distaste the Lovers above are growing

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: An index and obscure prologue to the history of lust and Roderigo recoils in revulsion. Iago protects Roderigo fro

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: But, sir, be you ruled by me. I have brought you from Ven

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Well?  Iago risks a cocky glimpse at the Camera.

dialogues.speaker: INT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Othello shuts the door behind him and looks around. He se

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue: That profit's yet to come 'tween me and you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roderigo rolls out from under the cart and dusts himself Iago, still beneath the cart, takes out his chess pieces

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) That Cassio loves her, I do well believe't: That she loves him, 'tis apt and of great credit. The Moor - howbeit that I endure him not - Is of a constant, loving, noble nature, And I dare think, he'll prove to Desdemona  A most dear husband. Now, I do love her too; Not out of absolute lust - though peradventure I stand accountant for as great sin - But partly led to diet my revenge, For that I do suspect the lusty Moor Hath leaped into my seat, the thought whereof He is instantly seething with anger and jealously.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Doth, like a poisonous mineral, gnaw my inwards,  And nothing can, or shall, content my soul  Til I am evened with him, wife for wife; or He drops the passion like an unwanted toy.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: ... failing so, yet that I put the Moor  At least into a jealousy so strong That judgment cannot cure. Which thing to do, I'll have our Michael Cassio on the hip, Abuse him to the Moor in the rank  A short reprise of the passion:

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: For I fear Cassio with my night-cap too Make the Moor thank me, love me, and reward me For making him egregiously an ass, And practicing upon his peace and quiet, Even to madness.  He gathers the chess pieces. He looks at the knight's poi Pocketing the king and queen, he leaves the knight under

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: 'Tis here, but yet confused: Knavery's plain face is never seen 'till used.  With the Lovers oblivious, the cart rolls out of sight, l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona and Othello approach each other slowly. She sta She pulls him over to the fireside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Armoury at the end of the Soldier's Quarters. Cassio,

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Welcome, Iago; we must to the watch.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Not this hour, Lieutenant; 'tis not yet ten o'th'clock. O

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: He hath not yet made wanton the night with her; and she i Cassio She is a most exquisite lady.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And, I'll warrant her, full of game.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: She is indeed perfection.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Well, happiness to their sheets! Come, Lieutenant, I have

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Not tonight, good Iago. I have very poor and unhappy brai

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O, they are our friends! But one cup; I'll drink for you.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I have drunk but one cup tonight already and dare not tas

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What, man! a night of revels; the gallants desire it.  Cassio considers. Iago smiles, infectiously.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) If I can fasten but one cup upon him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire blazes. Apple peel lies on the floor. Next to it Othello and Desdemona kiss passionately, their He takes it from her mouth and kisses her. He rolls the a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A band of Venetian and Cypriot SOLDIERS sit drinking by a

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (singing) And let me the canakin clink, clink; And let me the canakin clink; A soldier's a man O, man's life's but a span; Why, then, let a soldier drink.  (pause) Some wine, boys.  He pours more wine. They repeat the verse with the Veneti

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: 'Fore God, an excellent song.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I learned it in England, where indeed they are most poten

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: (proposing a toast) To the health of our General!  Montano arrives from the main hall.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I am for it, Lieutenant; and I'll do you justice.  The others cheer as Montano raises his tankard to meet Ca

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Drink ho!  They race each other to empty their tankards, accompanied

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O, sweet England. They congratulate each other. Bianca walks past.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Save you friend Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: How is't with you most fair...

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Bianca.  She pulls a ribbon from her hair and drops it in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello and Desdemona at the height of passion. Desdemona's arm stretches out over the side of the bed, h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello and Desdemona lie in each other's Arms.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: If it were now to die, 'Twere now to be most happy; for I fear My soul hath her content so absolute That not another comfort like to this Succeeds in unknown fate.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: The heavens forbid  But that our loves and comforts should increase  Even as our days do grow.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Amen to that, sweet powers.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (singing) 'Tin pride that pulls the country down; Then take thine auld cloak about thee.  It finishes on a haunting, melancholy note and Iago leave

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Let's have no more of this; let's to our affairs. God for He clambers to his feet, but has a little difficulty keep

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Do not think, gentlemen, I am drunk: This is my Ancient,

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Excellent well.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Why, very well; you must not think then that I am drunk.  Cassio concentrates on walking in a straight line. He suc Iago nods at Roderigo, who gets up and goes after Cassio. Montano gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: To the platform, master; come let's set the watch.  Iago moves in to have a quiet word with Montano.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You see this fellow that is gone before. He is a soldier fit to stand by Caesar And give direction; and do but see his vice.  Iago indicates the empty bottles at their feet.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: But is he often thus?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: 'Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep.  Roderigo returns at a run, hotly pursued by Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Zounds, you rogue, you rascal! (pause) What's the matter, Lieutenant?  (pause) A knave teach me my duty? I'll beat the knave into a twig

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Beat me?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Dost thou prate, rogue?  He strikes Roderigo with the back of his hand, knocking h

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Nay, good Lieutenant, I pray you, sir, hold your hand. Le

dialogues.speaker: MONTANO
dialogues.text: Come, come, you're drunk.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Drunk! He turns his sword on Montano, who draws his own.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Nay, good Lieutenant. God's will, gentlemen!  Cassio strikes at Montano. As the fight begins, Iago pick

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Away, I say; go and cry out a mutiny.  Roderigo runs out. We hear cries of "MUTINY!" Roderigo rings the Courtyard Bell. The Alarm is taken up Although there are now three men against him, Cassio's wi

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Help, ho! Lieutenant! Sir! Montana! Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIERS reach for their weapons. A bell starts ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIERS leave their posts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello moves quietly but quickly out of bed, while Desde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassio is surrounded. He swings a long burning log and sc

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: God's will, Lieutenant, hold!  Cassio is shocked at his action, Montano grabs him round

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Hold for your lives!  Montano's Men, enraged by his wounding, struggle to free

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Hold! The General speaks to you: Hold, for shame!

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What is the matter here, are we turned Turks? For Christian shams, put by this barbarous brawl.  The fighters stop as they see pikes and arrows leveled at

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: He that stirs next to carve for his own rage Holds his soul light: He dies upon his motion.  The fighters drop their weapons and shuffle into line.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Silence that dreadful bell: It frights the isle  From her propriety. What is the matter, masters?  Silence.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I pray you pardon me: I cannot speak.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Worthy Montano. What's the matter That you unlace your reputation thus And spend your rich opinion for the name Of a night-brawler? Give me answer to it.

dialogues.speaker: MONTANO
dialogues.text: Worthy Othello, I am hurt to danger. Your officer, Iago, can inform you,  While I spare speech, of all that I do know.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Now, by heaven,  My blood begins my safer guides to rule.  Give me to know, How this foul rout began, who set it on;  And he that is approved in this offense,  Though he had twinned with me, both at a birth,  Shall lose me. What! In a town of war  To manage private and domestic quarrel  In night, and on the court and guard of safety,  'Tis monstrous. On thy love I charge thee  Iago, who began't?

dialogues.speaker: MONTANO
dialogues.text: If partially affined or leagued in office,  Thou dost deliver more or less than truth,  Thou art no soldier.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Touch me not so near. I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth  Than it should do offence to Michael Cassio.  All eyes turn to Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Yet, I persuade myself to speak the truth Shall nothing wrong him. This it is , General.  He steps forward and stands to attention.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Montano and myself being in speech, There comes a fellow, crying out for help... And Cassio following him with determined sword To execute upon him. Sir, this gentleman Steps in to Cassio, and entreats his pause. Myself the crying fellow did pursue,  Lest by his clamour, as it so fell out, The town might fall in fright. He, swift of foot, Outran my purpose, and I returned, the rather For that I heard the clink and fall of swords And Cassio high in oath, which till tonight I ne'er might say before. when I came back - For this was brief - I found them close together At blow and thrust, even as again they were When you yourself did part them. More of this matter can I not report.  Iago drops his military tone for a confidential one.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: But men are men; the best sometimes forget. Though Cassio did some little wrong to him... As men in rage strike those that wish them best, Yet surely Cassio...

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I know, Iago, Thy honesty and love doth mince this matter, Making it light to Cassio. Cassio...  Othello approaches him. Cassio, reeling slightly, attempt

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I love thee, But nevermore be officer of mine.  Desdemona appears, attended by Emilia.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Look, if my gentle love be not raised up. I'll make thee an example.  Othello rips the lieutenant's sash from Cassio's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: What's the matter, dear?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: All's well now, sweeting: come away to bed. Sir, for your hurts myself will be your surgeon.  Othello leads Desdemona away.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: 'Tis the soldiers, life To have their balmy slumbers waked with strife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Cassio sinks to the ground. He is alone except for

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What, are you hurt... Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Ay, past all surgery.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Marry, God forbid!

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: O, I have lost my reputation I have lost the immortal par

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: As I am an honest man I thought you had received some bod He kneels to comfort Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What, man! There are ways to recover the General again. Y

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I would rather sue to be despised than to deceive so good

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What was he that you followed with your sword?  What had he done to you?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I know not.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Is't possible?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Drunk! O God, that men should put an enemy in their mouth

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Come, come; good Wine is a good familiar creature if it b He cannot resist a quick grin to the Camera.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Exclaim more against it. And good Lieutenant, I think you think I love you.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I have well approved it, sir. I drunk!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You or any man living may be drunk at a time, man. I'll t

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: You advise me well.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I protest in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.  He offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I think it freely...  Cassio accepts his hand and hauls him into an embrace. CLOSEUP on Iago who stares into the Camera.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (whispers) And what's he then that says I play the villain?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: ... and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuou They break apart.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me here.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You are in the right. Good night, Lieutenant, I must to t

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Good night, honest Iago.  With his hopes a little restored, Cassio leaves.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) How am I then a villain When this advice is free I give and honest,  Probal to thinking, and indeed the course to win the Moor His soul is so enfettered to Desdemona's love, That she may make, unmake, do what she list, Even as her appetite shall play the god With his weak function. How am I then a villain To counsel Cassio to this parallel course Directly to his good? Divinity of hell!  He is drawn to the fire again.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: When devils will the blackest sins put on, They do suggest at first with heavenly shows As I do now. For whiles this honest fool Plies Desdemona to repair his fortunes And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor, I'll pour this pestilence into his ear: That she repeals him for her body's lust.  He puts his hand on a charred log. It sizzles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And by how much she strives to do him good, She shall undo her credit with the Moor. So will I turn her virtue into pitch,  He draws his fingers down his face, smearing it black.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And out of her own goodness make the net That shall enmesh them all.  He embraces himself. His eyes closed in ecstasy. Fade to The sound of panting. The image returns as before as Iago

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: How now, Roderigo?  He turns to see Roderigo, battered and disheveled.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I do follow here in the chase, not like a hound that hunt Seething, he turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (calling out) How poor are they that have not patience  Roderigo stops, but doesn't turn back.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What wound did ever heal but by degrees?  Thou know'st we work by wit, and not by witchcraft, And wit depends on dilatory time. Does't not go well?  A faint gasp from Roderigo, who is on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Cassio hath beaten thee, And thou by that small hurt hath cashiered Cassio.  Roderigo turns slowly back. A grin breaks out on his face

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Content thyself awhile.  He puts his arm round Roderigo. Birds sing.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: By th' mass, 'tis morning: Pleasure and action make the hours seem short. Retire thee awhile.  Roderigo is sleepy and comfortable with his head resting

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Away, I say...  Roderigo starts to speak.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Iago thou shalt know more hereafter:  Roderigo tries again.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Iago Nay, get thee gone.  He goes. Iago turns sharply to the Camera:

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Two things are to be done.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress: I'll set he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along upper colonnade moving along to stairway area. Iago straps on his sword as Cassio enters in the backgrou

dialogues.speaker: IAGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Myself the while to draw the Moor apart,  And bring him jump when he may Cassio find  Soliciting his wife. Cassio and Emilia approach as Iago sets off past them.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Good morrow, good Lieutenant.  Cassio stops him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: (softly)  I humbly thank you.  Iago smiles, kisses Emilia firmly and hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) Ay, that's the way. Dull not device by coldness and delay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello, and Montano's Men in battle-dress stand on the b

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see it?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Bounteous madam, Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio, He's never anything but your true servant.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I know't; I thank you.  She opens the door. Cassio takes her hand and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Madam, here comes my lord.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Madam, I take my leave.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Why stay and hear me speak on thy behalf.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Madam, not now, I am very ill at ease, Unfit for mine own purposes.  Othello and Iago round a corner just Cassio disappears be

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (muttering) Ha! I like not that.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What dost thou say?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Nothing, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Cassio, my lord?  Othello walks past Desdemona into their bedroom. Iago fol

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: How now, my lord? I have been talking with a suitor here, A man that languishes in your displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Who is't you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Why, your lieutenant, Cassio.  Othello throws a look at Iago, who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Good my lord,  If he be not one that truly loves you,  I have no judgment in an honest face.  I prithee call him back.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Went he hence now?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Aye, soothe; so humbled That he hath left part of his grief with me To suffer with him. Good love, call him back.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Not now, sweet Desdemona; some other time.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: But shall't be shortly?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: The sooner, sweet, for you.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Shall't be tonight at supper?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: No, not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (playfully) Tomorrow dinner then?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I shall not dine at home. I meet the captains at the citadel.  Othello has removed his armour. She strokes and tickles h

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Why, then, tomorrow night, or Tuesday morn,  On Tuesday noon, or night; on Wednesday morn.  I prithee name the time, but let it not  Exceed three days.  She looks at him hopefully: He feigns lack of interest.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: When shall he come?  He looks at her blankly. She slaps his chest.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Tell me, Othello.  Again, no response; she starts to get riled:

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I wonder in my soul  What you would ask me that I should deny,  Or stand so mammering on.  He sighs, concealing a grin.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: What! Michael Cassio,  That came a-wooing with you, and so many a time  When I have spoke of you dispraisingly...  Her baiting receives a mere raised eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: ... Hath tane your part, to have so much to do  To bring him in? (passions blazing) By'r Lady, I could do much.  Othello breaks into laughter, joined by Iago and Emilia.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Prithee no more. Let him come when he will;  I will deny thee nothing.  She smiles, coolly. He goes to embrace her. She pulls awa

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Why, this is not a boon;  'Tis as I should entreat you wear your gloves,  Or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm,  Or sue to you to do a peculiar profit  To your own person. Nay, when I have a suit  Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed,  It shall be full of poise and difficult weight,  And fearful to be granted.  Though playful, the threat is meant. Othello respects it

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I will deny thee nothing.  They embrace warmly. They look into each other's eyes: a

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Whereon, I do beseech thee, grant me this, To leave me but a little to myself.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Shall I deny you? No; farewell, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Farewell, my Desdemona! I'll come to thee straight.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Emilia, come.  He watches her as she goes: elegant, more woman now than

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Be as your fancies teach you; Whate'er you be, I am obedient.  Her dignity belies any sense of servility. She leaves and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIERS training. Iago and Othello work together. Othello sees Desdemona wa

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Excellent wretch! Perdition catch my soul. But I do love thee, (to himself) And when I love thee not. Chaos is come again.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: My noble lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What dost thou say, Iago?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Did Michael Cassio When you wooed my lady, know of your love?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: He did from first to last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello sloshes water over his face.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Why dost thou ask?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: But for a satisfaction of my thought; No further harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello checks weapons.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Why of thy thought, Iago?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: O yes, and went between us very oft.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Indeed?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Indeed? Ay, indeed. Discern'st thou aught in that? Is he not honest?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Honest my lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Honest? Ay, honest.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: My lord, for aught I know.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What dost thou think?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Think, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Think, my lord! By heaven, he echoes me. Thou dost mean something. If thou dost love me, Show me thy thought.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: My lord, you know I love you.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I think thou dost; And for I know thou'rt full of love and honesty, And weighst thy words before thou giv'st them breath, Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: For Michael Cassio, I dare be sworn I think that he is honest.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I think so too.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Men should be what they seem; Or those that be not, would they might seem none!

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Certain, men should be what they seem.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why then, I think Cassio's an honest man.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Nay, yet there's more in this. I prithee speak to me as to thy thinkings, As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts  The worst of words.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Good my lord, pardon me; Utter my thoughts!

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago, If thou mak'st his ear a stranger to thy thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I do beseech you,  Though I perchance am vicious in my guess-  As I confess it is my nature's plague,  To spy into abuses and oft my jealousy  Shapes faults that are not - I entreat you then,  It were not for your quiet nor your good,  Nor for my manhood, honesty, and wisdom,  To let you know my thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What dost thou mean?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Good name in man and woman, dear my lord,  Is the immediate jewel of their souls.  Who steals my purse steals trash: 'Tis something, nothing 'Twas mine, 'tis his, and has been slave to thousands. But he that filches from me my good name Robe me of that which not enriches him And makes me poor indeed.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: By heaven, I'll know thy thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand; Nor shall not whilst 'tis in my custody. O beware, my lord of jealousy: It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock The meat it feeds on.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Why, why is this?  Think'st thou I'd make a life of jealousy,  To follow still the changes of the moon  With fresh suspicions? No, to be once in doubt  Is once to be resolved. Exchange me for a goat,  When I shall turn the business of my soul  To such exsufflicate and blown surmises,  Matching thy inference. 'Tis not to make me jealous  To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company,  Is free of speech, sings, plays and dances well:  Where virtue is these are more virtuous. No, Iago,  I'll see before I doubt; when I doubt, prove;  And on the proof, there is no more but this:  Away at once with love or jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I am glad of this; for now I shall have reason To show the love and duty that I bear you With franker spirit. Therefore, as I am bound, Receive it from me. I speak not yet of proof. Look to your wife, observe her well with Cassio; Look to't. I know our country disposition well: In Venice they do let Heaven see the pranks  They dare not show their husbands. Their best conscience Is not to leave't undone, but keep't unknown.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Dost thou say so?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: She did deceive her father, marrying you. And when she seemed to shake and fear your looks She loved them most.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: And so she did.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why, go to then! But I am much to blame. I humbly do beseech you of your pardon  For too much loving you.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I am bound to thee forever.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I see this hath a little dashed your spirits.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Not a jot, not a jot.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I'faith, I fear it has.  I hope you will consider what is spoke  Comes from my love. But I do see you're moved.  I am to pray you not to strain my speech  To grosser issues nor to larger reach  Than to suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I will not.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Should you do so, my lord, My speech should fall into such vile success As my thoughts aimed not at. Cassio's my worthy friend - My lord, I see you're moved.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: No, not much moved. I do not think but Desdemona's honest.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Long live she so... and long live you to think so.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: And yet how nature erring from itself -

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Ay, there's the point: as, to be bold with you,  Not to enter into any marriage  Of her own clime, complexion and degree, Whereto we see in all things nature tends -  Othello shuts his eyes in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow Motion Sequence: The first night in Cyprus. Desdemon

dialogues.speaker: IAGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Foh, one may smell in such a will most rank, Foul disproportion, thoughts unnatural.  Desdemona changes partner, from Montano to Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello opens his eyes: He stands in front of a mirror an

dialogues.speaker: IAGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But pardon me: I do not in position Distinctly speak of her, tho' I may fear Her will, recoiling to her better judgment, May fall to match you with her country forma And may perchance repent.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Farewell. If more thou dost perceive, let me know more. Leave me, Iago.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: My lord, I take my leave.  He starts to leave, but stops at the door and watches Oth

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: (muttering) Why did I marry?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (returning) My lord, I would I might entreat you honour To scan this thing no farther. Leave it to time. Let me be thought too busy in my fears As worthy cause I have to fear I am - And hold her free, I do beseech your honor.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Fear not my government. That we can call these delicate creatures ours And not their appetites  Iago goes. Othello wrenches at his ruff to loosen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona dancing among the VENETIANS. She moves from Mon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona, in a similar position and pose, stands in the

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: How now, my dear Othello? Your dinner and the generous islanders, By you invited, do attend your presence.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I am to blame.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Why do you speak so faintly? Are you not well?  She goes to him and sees that he's sweating. She takes ou

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Come, I'll go in with you. He goes and Desdemona follows.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I am very sorry that you are not well.  Emilia sees the handkerchief and picks it up. She stares

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night buzzes with insect noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassio lies in bed toying with the ribbon from Bianca's h She moves up to kiss him. He resists. He blows out the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago lies in bed. Emilia lays next to him. He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: I have a thing for you.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You have a thing for me? It is a common thing.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: To have a foolish wife.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O, is that all? What will you give me now For that same handkerchief?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What handkerchief?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: What handkerchief? Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona,  That which so often you did bid me to steal.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (sudden interest) Hast stolen it from her?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: No, faith: She let it drop by negligence,  She reveals a corner of the handkerchief between her brea

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: What will you do with't, that you Have been so earnest to have me filch it?  He smiles and rolls her over onto her back. She gasps at

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why what's that to you? Go, leave me.  He stares at her, coldly. Wounded, she turns to go. He gr

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) Trifles light as air Are to the jealous confirmations strong As proofs of holy writ. This may do something.  He tosses the handkerchief into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night of the dancing. Desdemona smiling in Cassio's a From amongst the VENETIANS behind them, a head turns slow

dialogues.speaker: BRABANTIO
dialogues.text: Look to her Moor, if thou hast eyes to see; She has deceived her father and may thee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello's eyes spring open.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: My life upon her faith.  He lies in bed with Desdemona sleeping by his side. He ga

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: If she be false, O then Heaven mocks itself; I'll not believe it.  He shuts his eyes, and is projected into another vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the trail of Desdemona's discarded clothes- as Othello's hand stretches out in front of us to the bedsid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello sits in bed, leaning over and staring intensely a He drops it and it thuds against the floor. Desdemona sti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona's arm is stretched over the bed, fingers splaye Groans of pleasure. A hand reaches out to grasp her (as O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello's eyes flash open and he drops her hand in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello leaves the Castle. In foreground Iago stalks him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago sits hidden amongst the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) The Moor already changes with my poison: Dangerous conceits are in their natures poisons, Which at the first are scarce found to distaste But, with a little act upon the blood, Burn like the mines of sulphur. I did say so. Look... He indicates Othello pacing on the shore.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Not poppy nor mandragora, Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world, Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep Which thou owed'st yesterday.  He joins Othello.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why, how now, general! No more of that.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Avaunt, be gone! Thou hast set me on the rack.  I swear 'tis better to be much abused, Than but to know't a little.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: How now, my lord!

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What sense had I of her stolen hours of lust? I saw't not, thought it not, it harmed not me. I found not Cassio's kisses on her lips.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I am sorry to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I had been happy if the general camp, Pioneers and all, had tasted her sweet body So I had nothing known. O now for ever Farewell the tranquil mind. Farewell content. Farewell the plumed troops, and the big wars That make ambition virtue - O farewell. Farewell the neighing steed and the shrill trump, The spirit-stirring drum, th'ear-piercing fife, The royal banner, and all quality, Pride, pomp and circumstance, of glorious war.  And, O you mortal engines, whose rude throats  Th'immortal Jove's dread clamours counterfeit,  Farewell. Othello's occupation's gone.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Is't possible, my lord?  Othello turns to Iago.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore; Be sure of it. Give me the ocular proof, Or by the worth of mine eternal soul, Thou hadst been better have been born a dog Than answer my waked wrath.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Is't come to this?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Make as to see't; or , at the least, so prove it That the probation bear no hinge nor loop To hang a doubt on - or woe upon thy life.  Othello grabs Iago by the throat.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: My noble lord -

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: It thou dost slander her and torture me,  Never pray more; abandon all remorse;  On horrors head horrors accumulate;  For nothing canst thou to damnation add  Greater than that.  His grip has tightened. He lets Iago drop. Iago backs awa

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O grace! O heaven defend me! God bu'y you; take mine office. To be direct and honest is not safe. I thank you for this profit and from hence I'll love no friend, sith love breeds such offense.  He starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Nay stay: Thou shouldst be honest.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I should be wise; for honesty's a fool And loses that it works for.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: By the world, I think my wife be honest, and think she is not: I think that thou art just, and think thou art not. I'll have some proof. Would I were satisfied!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion. I do repent me that I put it to you. You would be satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Would? Nay, I will.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And may. But how? How satisfied my lord? Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on? Behold her topped?  Othello punches him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Death and damnation!  Iago gets up and brushes off the sand.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: It were a tedious difficulty, I think, To bring them to that prospect. Damn them then What shall I say? Where's satisfaction? It is impossible you should see this, Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys  Othello grabs him again.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: But yet, I say, If imputation and strong circumstances, Which lead directly to the door of truth, Will give you satisfaction, you might have it.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Give me a living reason she's disloyal.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I do not like the office; But sith I am entered in this cause so far Pricked to it by foolish honesty and love I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately, And being troubled with a raging tooth I could not sleep. There are a kind of men so loose of soul  That in their sleeps will mutter their affairs. One of this kind is Cassio. In sleep I heard him say, 'Sweet Desdemona,  Lot us be wary, let us hide our loves.'  Othello sinks onto the sand. The sea laps at their ankles

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And then, air, would he grip and wring my hand,  Cry, 'O sweet creature!', and then kiss me hard,  As if he plucked up kisses by the roots  That grow upon my lips; then laid his leg  Over my thigh.  Iago illustrates, placing his own leg lightly over Othell

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And sighed, and kissed and then Cried.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK FANTASY
dialogues.text: Cassio whispering in Desdemona's ear. His lips move to ma

dialogues.speaker: IAGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Cursed fate that gave thee to the Moor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello pulls away and gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: O monstrous!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Nay, this was but his dream.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Monstrous!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Nay, yet be wise; yet we see nothing done, She may be honest yet. Tell me but this: Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief Spotted with strawberries in your wife's hand?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I gave her such a one; 'twas my first gift.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I know not that; but such a handkerchief -  I am sure it was your wife's - did I today  See Cassio wipe his beard with.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: If it be that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassio's hand catches the strawberry-spotted handkerchief Intrigued, he holds it up against the morning sunlight. He places it on a bed-post. He kisses the sleeping Bianca Meanwhile we hear the following:

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know not madam.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Believe me, I had rather lose my purse Full of crusadoes; and but my noble Moor Is true of mind and made of no such baseness As jealous creatures are, it were enough To put him to ill thinking.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is he not jealous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona still in her night-dress, rummages through her

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Who he? I think the sun where he was born Drew all such humours from him.  She turns and is startled to see standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: How is't with you, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Well, my good lady. How do you, Desdemona?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Well, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Give me your hand. This hand is moist, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: It has felt no age, nor known no sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart. Hot, hot and moist. This hand of yours requires A sequester from liberty, fasting and prayer, Much castigation, exercise devout; For there's a young and sweating devil here That commonly rebels. 'Tis a good hand, A frank one.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: You may indeed say so,  For 'twas that hand that gave away my heart.  Come now, your promise.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What promise, chuck?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I have bid Cassio come speak to you.  He drops her hand, putting his own to his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me: Lend me that handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Here, my lord.  She offers a plain, white handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: That which I gave you.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I have it not about me.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Not?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: No, faith, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: That's a fault. That handkerchief Did an Egyptian to my mother give: She was a charmer and could almost read The thoughts of people; she told her, while she kept it 'Twould make her amiable, and subdue my father Entirely to her love her but if she lost it, Or made a gift of it, my father's eye Should hold her loathly, and his spirits should hunt After new fancies: she dying, gave it me, And bid me when my fate would have me wive, I give it her. I did so, and take heed on it: Make it a darling, like your precious eye. To lose it or give't away were such perdition As nothing else could match.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Is't possible?  She is caught up in the intensity of his staring eyes.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: 'Tie true. There's magic in the web of it: The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk, And it was dyed in mummy, which the skillful Conserved of maiden's hearts.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I, faith, is't true?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Most veritable; therefore look to it well.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Then would to God I had never seen it.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: S'Blood!

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Why do you speak so startlingly and rash?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Is't lost? Is't gone? Speak; is't out of th'way?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Heaven bless us.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Say you?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: It is not lost, but what and if it were?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I say it in not lost.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Fetch it, let me see it.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Why so I can, sir; but I will not now. This is a trick to put me from my suit. Pray you let Cassio be received again.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Fetch me my handkerchief. My mind misgives.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Come, come; You'll never meet a more sufficient man.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: The handkerchief!

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I pray, talk me of Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: The handkerchief!

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
