dialogues.text: A man that all his time  Hath founded his good fortunes on your love,  Shared dangers with you -

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: The handkerchief!

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I'faith, you are to blame.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Zounds!  Othello storms out. Iago stands, unseen, outside the door

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Is not this man jealous?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I ne'er saw this before.  Emilia catches sight of Iago retreating down the corridor

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: 'Tis not a year or two shows us a man.  Iago is meant to hear this and he does. He turns to look

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: They are all but stomachs, and we all but food; They eat us hungerly, and when they are full, They belch us.  Iago turns away and goes.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Something sure of state Hath puddled his clear spirit.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: (turning back into the room)  Pray heaven it be, and no conception  Nor no jealous toy concerning you.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Alas the day I never gave him cause.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: But jealous souls will not be answered so. They are not ever jealous for the cause, But jealous for they're jealous. 'Tis a monster Begot upon itself, born on itself.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Heaven keep that monster from Othello's mind.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Lady, amen.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: A sequence of shots going down to the dungeons: We follow Othello down a narrow passageway - Othello desc The Camera catches him up and we push in to the back of h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lurch along the tunnel gathering pace.  Spiral staircase - we reel down the stairs and into the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a PRISONER chained to the wall as he turns his hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look again and see that it is a TURKISH PRISONER. Iago is checking the cells and throws food to the prisone

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: But if I give my wife a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What then?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why, then 'tis hers, my lord' and being hers, She may, I think, bestow't on any man. What If I had said I had seen him do you wrong? Or heard him say -

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Hath he said anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glimpse of Cassio whispering in Desdemona's ear.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: He hath, my lord; but be you well assured, No more than he'll unswear.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What hath he said?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Faith, that he did - I know not what he did.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figures writhe behind drapes. Moans and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Lie -

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: With her?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: With her, on her, what you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drapes are pulled back: Cassio and Desdemona making l

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Lie with her? Lie on her? Zounds that's fulsome. Lie with He starts to reel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A succession of rapid images flash in his head. Glimpses The sound of Othello's erratic breathing mingles with whi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Clear sky. A bright white handkerchief floats th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello falling and hitting the ground. His head cracks a Iago looks down at him.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Work on, My medicine, work! I Thus credulous fools are caught, And many worthy and chaste dames even thus, All guiltless, meet reproach.  The sound of footsteps. Iago bends dawn to Othello

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What ho, my lord! My lord, I say. Othello.  Cassio arrives.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: My Lord is fallen into an epilepsy. This is his second fit; he had one yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Rub him about the temples.  Cassio moves towards Othello, but Iago leads him outside.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (whispering) No, forbear. The lethargy must have his quiet course. If not, he foams at mouth and by and by Breaks out to savage madness. Look, he stirs. Do you withdraw yourself a little while; He will recover straight. When he is gone, I would on great occasion speak with you.  An Cassio goose Othello sits bolt upright and states at t

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) Did he confess it?  Iago, startled, flicks a suspicious look at the Camera.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Dost thou mock me?  Iago helps him up and dusts him off.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I mock you? No, by heaven. Good sir,  Whilst you were here, o'er whelmed with your grief, Cassio came hither.  Othello looks about, wildly.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I shifted him away.  And laid good scuse upon your ecstasy;  Bade him anon return and here speak with me,  The which he promised. Do but encave yourself,  And mark the jeers, the gibes and notable scorns  That dwell in every region of his face.  For I will make him tell the tale anew,  Where, how, how oft, how long ago and when  He hath and is again to cope your wife.  Marry patience.  Othello is on the verge of erupting. The sound of footste Iago hushes him and bundles him in to a cell with a DERAN

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Now will I question Cassio of Bianca. He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain From the excess of laughter.  Cassio is almost upon him, Iago gets even quieter:

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad.  Through the bars of his cell Othello looks into the Camer Iago greets Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: How do you now, lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: The worser that you give me that same title Whose want even kills me.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Ply Desdemona well and you are sure on't. (whispering) Now, if this suit lay in Bianca's power How quickly should you speed.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: (laughing) Alas, poor wretch.  Othello turns to his fellow prisoner:

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Look how he laughs already.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I think, I'faith, she loves me.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: She gives it out that you shall marry her. Do you intend it?  Cassio laughs heartily.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I marry her? What! I prithee, bear some charity to my wit Iago leads him closer to Othello's cell. Othello ducks do

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Faith, the cry goes that you shall marry her.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Prithee, say true.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I am a very villain else.  Iago and Cassio laugh. The Prisoner joins in.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: This is the monkey's own giving out. She hangs and lolls and weeps upon me, so hales and pulls He demonstrates on Iago. Othello seethes.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Before me, look where she comes.  Iago withdraws, leaning on the cell door, an Bianca arriv

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: How is it with you, my most fair Bianca?  She brings out the spotted handkerchief. Iago is ecstatic

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Whence came this? This is some token from a newer friend.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: No, by my faith.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Why, whose is it?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I know not. I found it in my chamber.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: A likely story that you should find it in your chamber an She throws it at him.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Give it to your hobby-horse, wheresoe'er you had it.  Laughing, Cassio takes her in his arms and calms her.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: How now, my sweet Bianca. How now, how now.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: If you'll come to supper tonight, you may. If you will no She marches off. Iago and Cassio laugh at her.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: After her, after her.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Faith, I must. She'll rail in the streets else.  He picks up the handkerchief and sets off, but Iago check

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Will you sup there?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Faith, I intend to.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Well, I may chance to see you; for I would very fain spea

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Prithee, come; will you?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (laughing) Go to, say no more.  Cassio runs off.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: How shall I murder him, Iago?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?  Othello nods.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And did you see the handkerchief?  The prisoner nods. Iago unlocks the door and Othello Steps out.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) O, that the slave had forty thousand lives,  One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.  A fine woman, a fair woman, a sweet woman.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Nay, you must forget that.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ay, let her rot and perish, and be damned tonight, for sh No, my heart is turned to stone: I strike it and  It hurts my hand. But yet the pity of it,  Iago. O, Iago, the pity of it, Iago. O, the world hath not a sweeter creature! She might lie by an emperor's side and command him tasks.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Nay, that's not your way.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Damn her lewd minx, Damn her! Cuckold met.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O, 'tis foul in her!

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: With mine officer!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: That's fouler.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Look here Iago, All my fond love thus do I blow to heaven: 'Tis gone. Arise black vengeance from thy hollow cell. Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne To tyrannous hate. Now by yond marble heaven, In the due reverence of a sacred vow I here engage my words.  Kneeling, he takes out a dagger and cuts the of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Do not rise yet.  Witness you ever-burning lights above,  You elements that clip us round about,  Witness that here Iago doth give up  The execution of his wit, hands, heart,  To wronged Othello's service. Let him command, And to obey shall be in me remorse,  What bloody business ever.  He takes Othello's knife and cuts his own palm.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I greet thy love,  Othello clasps Iago's bleeding hand to his. Blood runs do

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Get me some poison, Iago, this night. I'll not expostulat

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Do it not with poison; strangle her in her bed, even the

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Good, good. The justice of it pleases; very good -

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker. You shall hear

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Excellent good. Come, go with me apart. Now art thou my l Othello holds his arm out and Iago grasps it.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I am your own forever.  They fall into an embrace. Iago's eyes glisten with tears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello smartens his clothing. Iago puts on his new lieut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Venetian STANDARD-BEARERS among a small band of Atten Lodovico (the Duke's chess partner) kisses Desdemona's ha Othello and Iago enter.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: God save you, worthy general.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: With all my heart, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: The Duke and Senators of Venice greet you.  He gives Othello a letter. He takes it in his left hand.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I kiss the instrument of their pleasure. Welcome, signior Gratiano.  Gratiano grunts. Othello opens the letter and reads.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: And what's the news, uncle?  Gratiano grunts and turns away again.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Cousin Lodovico?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I am very glad to see you, signor; Welcome to Cyprus.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: I thank you. How does Lieutenant Cassio?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Lives, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Cousin, there's fallen between him and my lord An unkind breach; but you shall make all well.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: (muttering) Are you sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: (reading the letter) 'This fail you not to do, as you will -

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: He did not call; he's busy in the paper. Is there division between my lord and Cassio?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: A most unhappy one; I would do much T'atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio,  CLOSEUP on Othello's hand behind his back. He clenches ti

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Fire and brimstone!

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Are you wise?  Desdemona turns to Othello. His head is buried in the let

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: What, is he angry?

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Maybe the letter moved him;  For as I think they do command him home,  Deputing Cassio in his government.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: By my troth, I am glad on it.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I am glad to see you mad.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Why, sweet Othello?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Devil!  He strikes her across the face. The witnesses are shocked

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I have not deserved this.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: My lord, this would not be believed in Venice, Though I should swear I saw it. 'Tis very much. Make her amends; she weeps.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: If that the earth could teem with women's tears,  Each drops she falls would prove a crocodile.  Out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I would not stay to offend you.  She starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Truly, an obedient lady. I do beseech your lordship, call her back.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Mistress.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (stopping) My lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What would you with her, sir?

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Who? I, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn. Sir, she can turn... (he spins her round) ... and turn and yet go on,  And turn again. And she can weep, sir, weep.  And she's obedient; as you say, obedient,  Very obedient - proceed you in your tears -  He lurches from politeness to fury:

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Concerning this, sir. (the Letter; to Desdemona) O, well-painted passion. I am commanded home - get you away! I'll send for you anon. Sir, I obey the mandate, And will return to Venice - Hence avaunt. Desdemona runs off in tears.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Cassio shall have my place. And air, tonight I do entreat that we may sup together. You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus.  He bows and walks away, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Goats and monkeys!  Lodovico, amazed, watches him go. He turns to Iago:

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate Call all-in-all sufficient? Is this the nature Whom passion could not shake?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: He is much changed.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Are his wits safe? Is he not light of brain?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: He's that he is; I may not breathe my censure  What he may be.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: What, strike his wife!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (with great sadness) Faith, that was not so well; yet would I knew That stroke would prove the worst.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilia sits on a chair. Othello prowls around her.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: You have seen nothing then?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.  He moves in close to scrutinize her face. She battles to

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard Each syllable that breath made up between them.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What, did they never whisper?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Never, my lord I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, Lay down my soul at stake. If you think other,  Remove your thought; it doth abuse your bosom.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Bid her come hither; go. (to Camera) This is a subtle whore.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: What is your pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Let me see your eyes. Look in my face.  He grasps her face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: What horrible fancy's this?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What art thou?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Your wife, my lord; your true and loyal wife.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Come, swear it;  He grabs her by the hair and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... forces her to her knees by the altar.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Damn thyself; Swear thou art honest.  Heaven doth truly know it.  Othello reaches for his dagger.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Heaven truly knows thou art false as hell.  She looks up at him, unaware of his outstretched arm.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: To whom, my lord? With whom? How am I false?  His hand curls into a fist and he pushes her towards the

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ah, Desdemona, away, away, away.  He collapses onto the ground in tears. She gathers him up

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Alas, the heavy day. Why do you weep? Am I the motive of these tears my lord?  She kisses him about the face.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Had it pleased heaven  To try me with affliction, had they rained All kind of sores and shames on my bare head,  I should have found in some place of my soul  A drop of patience. But alas there where I have garnered up my heart, Where either I must live, or bear no life, The fountain from the which my current runs, Or else dries up - to be discarded thence Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads To knot and gender in! O, thou, who art so lovely fair and smell'st So sweet that the sense aches at thee, Would thou hadst ne'er been born.  She recoils in shock.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed? He grabs her by the hair and pulls her head back.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,  Made to write 'whore, upon? What committed!  Impudent strumpet!  He kisses her forcefully, pins her down and molests her.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: By heaven, you do me wrong.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Are you not a strumpet?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: No, as I am a Christian. If to preserve this vessel for my lord From any hated foul unlawful touch, Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What! Not a whore?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: No, and I shall be saved.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Is't possible?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: O, heaven forgive us.  He releases her and straightens her dress.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I cry you mercy then:  I took you for that cunning whore of Venice  That married with Othello.  He shouts at the door:

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: You, mistress, That have the office opposite to Saint Peter,  And keeps the gate of hell.  Emilia enters tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: You, you, ay, you. We have done our course;  He presses coins into her hands, which fall to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: there's money for your pains. I pray you turn the key, and keep our counsel.  He winks at her and leaves. Emilia rushes over to Desdemo

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: How do you, madam? How do you, my good lady?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (faintly) Faith, half-asleep.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Good madam, what's the matter with my lord?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: With who?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Why, with my lord, madam.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Who is thy lord?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: He that is yours, sweet lady.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I have none. Do not talk to me, Emilia. I cannot weep, nor answers have I none But what should go by water. Prithee tonight Lay on my bed my wedding sheets, remember; And call thy husband hither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona stands by the window staring at the bright moon

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Am I that name, Iago?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What name fair lady?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Such as my lord did say I was.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: He called her whore.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why did he so?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I do not know, I am sure I am none such.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Do not weep, do not weep: Alas the day!

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Has she forsook so many noble matches, Her father, and her country, all her friends, To be call'd whore? would it not make one weep?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: It is my wretched fortune.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Beshrew him for it. How comes this trick upon him?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Nay, heaven doth know. O' good Iago. What shall I do to win my lord again? Good friend, go to him; for, by this light of heaven, I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel:  She kneels in front of the altar-piece. Iago closes the s

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love Either in discourse of thought or actual deed; Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense Delighted them in any other form; Or that I do not yet, and ever did And ever will - though he do shake me off To beggarly divorcement - love him dearly, Comfort forswear me. Unkindness may do much, And his unkindness may defeat my life, But never taint my love. I cannot say 'whore: It does abhor me now I speak the word; To do the act that might the addition earn Not the world's mass of vanity could make me.  She sobs again. Iago gets to his knees to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I pray you be content; 'tis but his humour. The business of the state does him offense, And he does chide with you.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: If 'twere no other -

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: It is but so, I warrant.  Trumpets sound. He raises her up and embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Hark how these instruments summon to supper. The messengers of Venice stay the meat. Go in, and weep not; all things shall be well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Desdemona and Emilia move away, Iago is suddenly pulle

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: How now, Roderigo?

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I do not find that thou deal'st justly with me.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What in the contrary?

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Every day thou daff'st me with some device, Iago tries to speak.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I will indeed no longer endure it. Nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what  already I have foolishly suffered.  He presses harder with the sword-point.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Will you hear me, Roderigo?

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Faith, I have heard too much; for your Words and performance are no kin together.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You charge me most unjustly.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: With naught but truth. I have wasted myself out of my mea Iago pushes the sword away.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Well, go to; very well.  Roderigo pulls him back and slaps him.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Very well, go to? I cannot go to, man, nor 'tis not very He slaps Iago again.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (coolly) Very well.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I tell you 'tis not very well. I will make myself known t Roderigo pulls off his false beard. Iago turns slowly bac

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: If she will return me my jewels, I will give over my suit

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: You have said now.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doi He sets off after Desdemona. Iago swings him back.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why, now I see there's mettle in thee, and even from this He leads him away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: It hath not appeared.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I grant it hath not appeared; and your suspicions are not

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Well... what is it?  Iago smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello, Desdemona, Lodovico and Gratiano eat in silence. Lodovico looks at Desdemona. She manages a smile, he smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago and Roderigo in heated discussion.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Why, then Othello and Desdemona return again to Venice!

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Unless his abode be lingered here by some accident; where

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (nervously) How do you mean 'removing' of him?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Why, by making him incapable of Othello's place - knockin

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: And that you would have me to do?  Iago hushes him.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Ay, if you dare do yourself profit and a right. I will be

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: I will hear further reason for this.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: And you shall be satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello, Desdemona Lodovico and Gratiano walk in silence

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: O pardon me; 'twill do me good to walk. O Desdemona.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Get you to bed on the instant. I will return forthwith. D She freezes.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Look it be done.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I will, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Madam, good night. I humbly thank your ladyship.  He kisses her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Your honour is most welcome.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Will you walk, air?  She leaves. They set off down the stair/path to front gat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilia pours a bucket of hot water into a bath.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Dismiss me?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: It was his bidding.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: I would you had never seen him.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (forcefully) So would not I.  Emilia turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (calling out) Prithee... (Emilia turns back) unpin me here  Emilia helps her undress.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: All's one. Good faith, how foolish are our minds. If I do die before thee, prithee shroud me In one of those same sheets.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Come, come, you talk.  Desdemona starts to hum distractedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is lost in clouds. Othello parts company with Lodovico and Gratiano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona slips into a steaming bath.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: My mother had a maid called Barbary: She was in love and he she loved proved mad And did forsake her. She had a song of willow; An old thing 'twas but it expressed her fortune, And she died singing it. That song tonight Will not go from my mind.  (sings) The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree, Sing all a green willow; Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee, Sing willow, willow, willow; The fresh streams ran by her and murmured her moans: Sing willow, willow, willow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello's still silhouette amongst a patch of reeds thras He turns away and moves inland. Throughout:

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (singing V.O.) Her salt tears fell from her and softened the stones Sing willow, willow, willow. Prithee, hie thee; he'll come anon Sing all a green willow must be my garland.  Let nobody blame him: his scorn I approve  Nay, that's not next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desdemona is now in her night-dress.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Hark, who is't that knocks?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: It is the wind.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: This Lodovico is a proper man.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: A very handsome man.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: He speaks well.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: I know a lady in Venice, who would have walked barefoot t

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (sings) I called my love false love, but what said he then? Sing willow, willow, willow; If I court more women, you'll couch with more men. She gets into bed.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: So, get thee gone; good night. I do not think there is an Emilia starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Mine eyes do itch - Does that bode weeping?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: (hovering at the door) 'Tis neither here nor there.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I have heard it said so. O, these men, these men. Dost thou in conscience think - tell me, Emilia  That there be women do abuse their husbands  In such gross kind?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: (returning) There be some such, no question.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Why, would not you?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: No, by this heavenly light;

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Nor I by this heavenly light; I might do't as well i'th'dark.  They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: The world's a huge thing; it is a great price for a small

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: In troth, I think thou wouldst not.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: In troth, I think I should, and undo't again when I had d

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I do not think there is any such woman.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Yes... a dozen.  They laugh. Desdemona falls silent, apparently distracted

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: But I do think it is their husbands' faults  If wives do fall. Say that they slack their duties,  And pour our treasures into foreign laps;  O else break out in peevish jealousies,  Throwing restraint upon us; or say they strike us  Why, we have galls, and though we have some grace,  Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know  Their wives have sense like them: They see and smell  And have their palates both for sweet and sour,  As husbands have. What is it that they do  When they change us for others? Is it sport?  I think it is. And doth affection breed it?  I think it doth. Is't frailty that thus errs?  I think so too. And have not we affections,  Desires for sport, and frailty, as man have?  Then lot them use us well: else let them know,  The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.  Desdemona's eyes are shut. Emilia gets up gently. Desdemo

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Good, night, good night.  Emilia kisses her on the head and goes.  Desdemona settles into the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roderigo hovers nervously in a colonnade. He hears runnin

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Be near at hand; I may miscarry in it.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Here at thy hand; be bold and take thy stand.  Iago slips behind the next pillar and pulls out his dagge

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (muttering) 'Tis but a man gone. Forth my sword.  Roderigo takes out his rapier.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Camera) If Cassio do remain He hath a daily beauty in his life  That makes me ugly, and beside, the moor  May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril: No, he must die.  Sound of footsteps approaching. Cassio walks past Roderig

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: Villain, thou diest!  Cassio turns to face him and draws his sword. Iago peers Iago strikes at Cassio's back. At the same time Cassio lu Roderigo, in a state of shock, stumbles against a pillar,

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: O villain that I am.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: O help, ho! Murder! Murder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello enters the castle. Hearing the cries, he smiles i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lodovico and Gratiano appear at the other and of the colo Cassio cries out again.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: 'Tis some mischance; the cry is very direful.  Hearing them. Cassio's voice finds new power.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: O, help!

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Hark.  They move cautiously in Cassio's direction.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: O, wretched villain.  Hearing this cry from another direction, they start to wi

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Who's there? Whose noise is this that cries on murder?

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: We do not know.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Did not you hear a cry?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Here, here; for heaven's sake, help me!  Iago finds Cassio with his torchlight.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Iago? Give me some help.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O me, lieutenant. What villains have done this?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: I think that one of them is hereabout And cannot make away.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O, treacherous villains.  He calls out to Lodovico and Gratiano:

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What are you there? Come in and give some help.

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: (faintly) O, help me here.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: That's one of them.  Iago finds Roderigo crumpled behind a pillar.  He helps him up and smiles at him. Then he clamps one han

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (loudly) O murderous slave, O, villain.  Roderigo clings onto Iago and, as he sinks down, stares i

dialogues.speaker: RODERIGO
dialogues.text: O damned Iago. O inhuman dog.  Iago looks blankly at the Camera, then turns away.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (shouting) Where be these bloody thieves?  He moves up behind Cassio. Looking about, he sees no one Hearing footsteps he hides his dagger and spins round, sh

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Ho. murder, murder.  The figures of Lodovico and Gratiano emerge from the shad

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What may you be? Are you of good or evil?

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: As you shall prove us, praise us.  Lodovico and Gratiano stop into the torchlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distant shouts of 'Murder, murder'. SOLDIERS rush past th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello shuts out the sound as he closes the door behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lodovico holds a torch over Iago, who has taken off his n Attendants arrive, bringing more light. Bianca runs in. She sees Cassio and throws herself to the ground by his s

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: O, my dear Cassio, my sweet Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Patience awhile, good Cassio. Come, come, Lend me a light.  He leads them over to Roderigo

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Know we this face or no? Alas, my friend and my dear countryman. Roderigo? No -  He leans in with a torch.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: - yes, sure - O heaven, Roderigo.

dialogues.speaker: GRATIANO
dialogues.text: What, of Venice?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Even he, sire; did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: GRATIANO
dialogues.text: Know him? Ay.  Attendants arrive with a stretcher. Iago returns to Cassi

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: How do you, Cassio? He that lies slain here, Cassio, was

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: None in the world, nor do I know the man.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: (to Bianca) What, look you pale? - O, bear him out of the air.  Cassio is carried away. A SOLDIER throws Roderigo over hi Iago stops Lodovico and Gratiano:

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Stay you good gentlemen. Look you pale, mistress?  He brings the torch close up to her face.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Behold her well; I pray you. look upon her. Do you see, gentlemen? Nay, guiltiness Will speak, though tongues were out of use.  Emilia arrives.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: 'Las, what's the matter? What's the matter, husband?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Cassio hath here been set on in the dark. And almost slain.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Alas, good Cassio.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: This is the fruits of whoring. Prithee, Emilia, Go know of Cassio where he supped tonight. (to Bianca) What, do you shake at that?

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: He supped at my house, but I therefore shake not.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: O, did he so? I charge you go with me He grabs her roughly by the arms.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O, fie upon thee, strumpet.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: I am no strumpet, but of life as honest As you that thus abuse me.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: As I? Foh! Fie upon thee.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Kind gentlemen, let's go see poor Cassio dressed. Come mi Lodovico leaves with Gratiano. SOLDIERS drag Bianca along Iago tosses the 'black king', and the 'white queen' chess

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: (whispers to Camera) It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul:  He stands by the window, holding a candle. The shutters a

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars. It is the cause.  He closes the shutters and turns to the sleeping Desdemon

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Yet I'll not shed her blood.  Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow  And smooth as monumental alabaster  Yet she must die, else she'll betray more men.  Put out the light, and then put out the light:  If I quench thee, thou flaming minister,  I can again thy former light restore,  Should I repent me; but once put out thy light,  Thou cunning'st pattern of excelling nature,  I know not where is that Promethean heat  That can thy light relume. When I have plucked thy rose, I cannot give it vital growth again: It needs must wither. I'll smell it on the tree.  He leans in close to her. Her breathing is slow and stead

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: O balmy breath, that doth almost persuade  Justice to break her sword. One more, one more.  He kisses her again.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee  And love thee after. One more, and this the last. So sweet was ne'er so fatal.  He emits a sudden sob. She stirs; he moves swiftly away.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Who's there? (silence) Othello?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ay, Desdemona.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Will you come to bed, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Have you prayed tonight, Desdemona?

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Ay, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: If you bethink yourself of any crime Unreconciled as yet to heaven and grace, Solicit for it straight.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Alas, my lord, what may you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Well do it, and be brief: I will walk by. I would not kill thy unprepared spirit; No - heaven forfend - I would not kill thy soul.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Talk you of killing?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ay, I do.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Then heaven Have mercy on me.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Amen, with all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: If you say so, I hope you will not kill me. And yet I fear you Some mortal passion shakes your very frame:

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Think on thy sins.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: They are loves I bear to you.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: And for that thou diest.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: That death's unnatural, that kills for loving. She tries to take hold of him. He barks:

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Peace, and be still.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: I will so. What's the matter.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: That handkerchief which I so loved and gave thee, Thou ga

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: No, by my life and soul. Send for the man and ask him.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Sweet soul, take heed. Take heed of perjury: Thou art on thy death-bed.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Ay, but not yet to die.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Yes, presently.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Then Lord have mercy on me.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I say, Amen.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (forcefully) And have you mercy too. I never did  Offend you in my life; never loved Cassio  But with such general warranty of heaven  As I might love. I never gave him token.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: By heaven, I saw my handkerchief in his hand.  O perjured woman...

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: He found it then;  I never gave it him. Send for him hither;  Let him confess a truth.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: He hath confessed.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: What, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: That he hath used thee.  Desdemona is struck dumb with shock.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: How? Unlawfully?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ay -

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: He will not say so.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: No, his mouth is stopped: Honest Iago hath tane order for it.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: O, my fear interprets. What, is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lodovico, Gratiano, Emilia and Iago escorting the wounded Roderigo's body is thrown onto the table. He emits the fa

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Emilia, run and tell my lord and lady what hath happed.  She leaves. He turns to the Camera.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: This is the night, That either makes me or fordoes me quite.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Had all his hairs been lives, my great revenge  Had stomach for them all.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Alas, he is betrayed and I undone.  She buries her head in her hands. He flings her hands asi

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Out, strumpet. Weep'st thou for him to my face?  He throws her down on the bed. She springs up at him, kno

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilia runs along a corridor.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: O, banish me, my lord, but kill me not.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Down strumpet.  He throws her down again and fixes her with a stare.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Kill me tomorrow; let me live tonight.  He moves slowly towards her. She slaps him. He keeps adva

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Nay, if you strive -

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: But half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Being done, there is no pause.  He picks up a pillow, she writhes beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: But while I say one prayer.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: It is too late.  She stops fighting and looks into his eyes, her own eyes Behind them, fire starts to climb the drapes. Her arms ar

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: O, Lord, Lord, Lord.  He body bucks beneath him, but the pillow stays firmly in

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: My lord, my lord. What, ho. My lord, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What, not dead? Not yet quite dead? He picks up the pillow again.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: What, ho! My lord, my lord!

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: O, good my lord, I would speak a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Yes - Emilia - by and by.  A slice of moonlight as Othello opens a shutter. The ligh

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Still as the grave. (he turns to the Camera) Shall she come in? Were't good?  I think she stirs again. No. What's best?  If she come in, she'll sure speak to my wife  My wife, my wife. What wife? I have no wife.  He cradles her.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: I do beseech you That I may speak with you. O, good my lord.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I had forgot thee, Emilia. Soft, by and by.  He gently replaces Desdemona and straightens the bedsheet

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What's the matter with thee now.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O, my good lord, yonder's foul murder done.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What? Now?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: But now, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: It is the very error of the moon: She comes more nearer earth than she was wont And makes men mad.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Cassio, my lord, hath killed a young Venetian Called Roderigo.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Roderigo killed? And Cassio killed?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: No, Cassio is not killed.  Emilia sees a little stream of water trickling out under

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Not Cassio killed. Then murder's out of tune, And sweet revenge grows harsh.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: (faintly) O falsely, falsely murdered.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O Lord. What cry is that?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: That? What?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Out and alas, that was my lady's voice. She pushes past Othello, and past the drape to Desdemona.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Help, help, ho help. O lady, speak again. Sweet Desdemona, o sweet mistress, speak.

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: A guiltless death I die.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O, who has done this deed?  Othello stands at the end of the bed. She looks up at him

dialogues.speaker: DESDEMONA
dialogues.text: Nobody; I myself. Farewell. Commend me to my kind lord. O farewell. She dies. Silence. Emilia gets to her feet and heads for the door. Othello s

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Why, how should she be murdered?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Alas, who knows? She tries to move round him, but he won't let her.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: You heard her say herself it was not I.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: She said so; I must needs report the truth. He moves aside. She gets to the door.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: She's like a liar gone to burning hell: 'Twas I that killed her.  She turns back.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O, the more angel she, And you the blacker devil.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: She turned to folly and she was a whore.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Thou dost belie her and thou are a devil.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: She was false as water.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Thou art rash as fire to say That she was false. O, she was heavenly true.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Cassio did top her: Ask thy husband else. O, I were damned beneath all depth in hell But that I did proceed upon just grounds To this extremity. Thy husband knew it all.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: My husband?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Thy husband.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: That she was false to wedlock?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ay, with Cassio. Nay, had she been true -

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: My husband?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ay, 'twas he that told me on her first.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: My husband?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: What needs this iterance, woman? I say thy husband.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O, mistress, villainy hath made mocks with love. My husba

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: He, woman; I say thy husband. Dost understand the word? My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: If he say so, may his pernicious soul Rot half a grain a day. He lies to the heart. She was too fond of her filthy bargain.  Othello snatches his battle-scarred sword from the wall. Emilia doesn't flinch.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Do thy worst. This deed of thine is no more Worthy heaven than thou wast worthy her. Help! Murder!

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: (raising his sword) Peace, you were best.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Thou hast not half the power to do me harm As I have to be hurt. O gull. O dolt. As ignorant as dirt. Thou hast done a deed - I care not for thy sword - I'll make thee known, Though I lost twenty lives. Help! Help! Ho, help! The Moor hath killed my mistress. Murder, murder!  Othello drops the sword and Emilia runs for the door, but

dialogues.speaker: MONTANO
dialogues.text: What is the matter? How now, general? Othello stands rigid and staring.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O, are you come, Iago? You have done well. That men must lay their murders on your neck.

dialogues.speaker: GRATIANO
dialogues.text: What is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Disprove this villain, if thou be'st a man.  He says thou told'st him that his wife was false.  I know thou didst not. thou'rt not such a villain. Speak, for my heart is full. All eyes but Othello's turn to Iago.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I told him what I thought, and told no more Than what he found himself was apt and true.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: But did you ever tell him she was false?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: You told a lie, an odious damned lie: Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie. She false with Cassio? Did you say with Cassio?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: With Cassio, mistress. Go to, charm your tongue.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: I will not charm my tongue; I am bound to speak: My mistr She pulls the drape aside to reveal Desdemona's body. The WITNESSES are horrified.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: And your reports have set the murder on.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Nay, stare not, masters; it is true indeed.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Villainy, villainy, villainy. I think upon it , I think - I smell't - O villainy.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: What are you mad? I charge you get you home.  He tries to push her out. Othello looks across at him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Good gentlemen, lot me have leave to speak. 'Tin proper I obey him, but not now. Perchance, Iago, I will ne'er go home.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: Othello falls onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Nay, lay thee down and roar, For thou hast killed the sweetest innocent That e'er did lift up eye.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: (leaping up again) Or she was foul. Iago knows That she with Cassio hath the act of shame A thousand times committed. Cassio confessed it, And she did gratify his amorous works With that same handkerchief. I saw it in his hand:

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O god. O heavenly God. She turns to Iago.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Be wise and get you home.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: I will not. Iago draws his sword on Emilia. All eyes turn to Iago.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: O thou dull moor, that handkerchief thou speak'st of  I found by fortune and did give my husband.

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Filth, thou liest.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: By heaven, I do not, I do not gentlemen. I found it -

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Are there no stones in heaven  But what serves for thunder? Precious villain.  Othello picks up his sword and runs at Iago; Montano inte Iago puts a dagger to Emilia's throat and drags her to th As he runs out of the room, he stabs her in the back.  Emilia stands still for a moment, then topples to the gro

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: Lay me by my mistress side.  They do so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago sprints across the main hall, scrabbling over a tabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago runs as Montano and his men chase him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago running, the sound of footsteps not far behind. He t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens with relief as the footsteps pass the door. He turns to see: Cassio being tended by SURGEONS. Roderig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilia lies by Desdemona.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIA
dialogues.text: What did thy song bode, lady? Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan And die in music: (sings) 'Willow, willow willow' Moor, she was chaste; she loved thee, cruel moor; So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true; So speaking as I think, I die, I die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago remains unseen at the door. Roderigo's eyes slowly o Iago turns to open the door and comes face to face with M Iago slips out his dagger, but is knocked to the ground b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello is on the bed, poring over Desdemona's body.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Now, how dost thou look now? O ill-starred wench.  Pale an thy smock. Cold, cold, my girl,  Even like thy chastity  O cursed, cursed slave. Whip me, ye devils,  From the possession of this heavenly sight.  Blow me about in winds! Roast me in sulphur!  Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire! O Desdemona. Lodovico arrives with Cassio, on crutches, and soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Where is this rash and most unfortunate man?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: That's he that was Othello: Here I am.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Where is that viper? Bring the villain forth.  Montano brings Iago in. He is tied hand and foot and his

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I look down towards his feet; but that's a fable. If that He draws one of the soldier's swords and thrusts it into

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: I bleed, sir, but not killed.  Iago is pulled off and thrown to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I am not sorry neither; I'd have thee live, For in my sense 'tis happiness to die.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: his wretch hath part confessed his villainy. Did you and he consent in Cassio's death?

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Ay.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: Dear general, I never gave you cause.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I do believe it and ask you pardon. Will you, I pray demand that demi-devil Why he hath thus ensnared my soul and body?

dialogues.speaker: IAGO
dialogues.text: Demand me nothing; what you know, you know. From this time forth I never will speak word.  He looks once into the Camera and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: What! Not to pray?

dialogues.speaker: GRATIANO
dialogues.text: Torments will ope your lips.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Well, thou dost best.  Gratiano spins round and spits in Othello's face.  Othello sees there is a growing menace in the soldier's f

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: You must forsake this room and go with us. Your power and your command is taken off And Cassio rules in Cyprus.  Cassio extends his hand to Othello. They clasp hands. Oth He glimpses the small ruby-studded dagger that he gave Ca

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Come, bring him away.  Soldiers take hold of him. He grabs a bed-post.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: Soft you: a word or two before you go.  The soldiers pull aggressively but he won't let go.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I have done the state some service and they know it. Lodovico motions to the Soldiers to release him.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I pray you, in your letters When you shall these unlucky deeds relate, Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate, Nor set down aught in malice. Then must you speak  Of one that loved not wisely, but too well;  Of one not easily jealous, but, being wrought,  Perplexed in the extreme; of one whose hand,  Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away  Richer than all his tribe; of one whose subdued eyes,  Albeit unused to the melting mood, Drops tears as fast as the Arabian trees, Their medicinable gum. Set you down this; And say besides that in Aleppo once Where a malignant and a turbaned Turk Beat a Venetian and traduced the state, I took by the throat the circumcised dog And smote him thus.  He pulls out the dagger and drives it into his heart.  Iago gasps and falls to his knees. Cassio prevents the ot Othello climbs onto the bed and over to Desdemona.

dialogues.speaker: OTHELLO
dialogues.text: I kissed thee ere I killed thee: No way but this, Killing myself, to die upon a kiss. With his lips pressed to here, he dies.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIO
dialogues.text: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon, For he was great of heart.  Lodovico drags Iago over to the foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LODOVICO
dialogues.text: Look on the tragic loading of this bed: This is thy work. (to Cassio) To you, lord governor,  Remains the censure of this hellish villain:  The time, the place, the torture, O, enforce it.  Myself will straight aboard, and to the state  This heavy act with heavy heart relate.  He leaves the room. All follow except Cassio and Iago  Cassio goes to the window, opens the shutters and looks o Iago has worked his way onto the bed. He pushes Emilia as Dawn breaks. More light spills into the room, colour with Iago lays his head on Othello's thigh and stares into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises over the sea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness except for glints of metal, and silence but for Iago's eyes. In the shadows we glimpse instruments of tor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassio, in general's uniform, stands on the prow of a boa A linen wrapped package is tipped into the water by two a

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Beneath the surface. The sun glares through the water. We

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose petals float on the water.
